Title: Wall hanging, Mapula Embroidery Project, Winterveldt, Gauteng, South Africa
Summary: This embroidery celebrates the late Nelson Mandela’s life and leadership in a free and democratic South Africa. The name of Bernlhee Daniels, Miss South Africa, 1995, appears on the cloth, as does the name of South Africa’s former first lady, Mrs. Graça Machel Mandela, who married Mandela in 1998. Pretoria’s twin-towered Union Buildings—the official seat of South Africa’s government and the site of Mandela’s inauguration as president—also appear in the background.
Name.creator: Ringane, Elisa Phazimane
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: Mapula Embroidery Project

Title: Wall hanging, Mapula Embroidery Project, Winterveldt, Gauteng, South Africa
Summary: This embroidery, which was created to honor the eighty-fifth birthday of Nelson Mandela, conveys the deep affection and respect felt by many South Africans for their former president and leader of the anti-apartheid struggle. Madiba and Tata—both terms of endearment—are the two names most commonly used by South Africans for Mandela. Madiba was Mandela’s clan name and tata means “father” in Xhosa, Mandela’s mother tongue.
Name.creator: Maepa, Rosina Ngwakwane
Name.subject: Mandela, Nelson, 1918-2013
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: Mapula Embroidery Project

Title: Wall hanging, Mapula Embroidery Project, Winterveldt, Gauteng, South Africa
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: Mapula Embroidery Project

Title: Wall hanging, Mapula Embroidery Project, Winterveldt, Gauteng, South Africa
Summary: This embroidery draws inspiration from educational materials for the prevention of hiv/aids, which include slogans, pamphlets, posters, and billboards. The embroidery also speaks to everyday concerns among women in a country where as many as one in four live with HIV.
Name.creator: Maseko, Jane
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: Mapula Embroidery Project

Title: Embroidered panels, Kaross Workers, Tzaneen, South Africa
Summary: This embroidery is part of a larger group that was commissioned to be distributed at “Breaking the Silence,” the 12th International aids Conference held in Durban in 2000. Each participant in the project was given a small panel on which she portrayed the effects of aids on her community.
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection

Title: Wall hanging, Mapula Embroidery Project, Winterveldt, Gauteng, South Africa

Title: Wall hanging, Kaross Workers, Tzaneen, South Africa
Summary: The Kaross Workers include both men and women. Men typically draw the designs and women embroider them. Calvin Mahlaule, the designer of this embroidery, is one of the most prominent associated with the Kaross Workers initiative. In an image with biblical overtones, Mahlaule explores the potent mix of Christian belief, sexuality, death, and suffering that shapes the experience of hiv and aids in southern Africa. Suggesting struggles with temptation and restraint, figures reminiscent of Adam and Eve stand on either side of the Tree of Knowledge. Although the figures appear robust and in their prime, they are covered with red spots that connote disease.
Name.creator: Mahlaule, Calvin
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: Kaross Workers

Title: Wall hanging, KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa
Contents note: Zulu text: Into engayibona kwakuliwa impi, kuleyompi kwafa indodana yenkosi. Yadinwa kakhulu inkosi yabulala bonke abantu abasinda kwakufa indodana yayo. Translation: Something I saw in the faction fight, the son of the King died in that fight. The King was so angry and then he decided to kill all the people who survive when his son died.
Format.medium: beads and cotton thread on cotton
Name.creator: Ngema, Fokisile
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: KwaZulu-Natal Province

Title: Wall hanging, KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa
Contents note: Zulu text: Ngabona izimoto ezimbili zishayisana, enyeyazo ibheke phezulu udilayiva wayo eseshonile kwakungumzala wami. Translation: I saw the two cars in an accident, one of the cars was upside down and the driver was dead. When I looked close, it was my cousin.
Format.medium: beads and cotton thread on cotton
Name.creator: Ximba, Lobolile
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: KwaZulu-Natal Province

Title: Wall hanging, KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa
Contents note: Zulu text: Wangishaya kabuhlungu ubaba wami, edliswe ushevu. Translation: My father died so painfully, he was poisoned by his enemies.
Format.medium: beads and cotton thread on cotton
Name.creator: Ximba, Lobolile
Repository: William H. Worger and Nancy L. Clark Personal Collection
Subject: KwaZulu-Natal Province

Title: Wall hanging, KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa

Format.medium: beads and cotton thread on cotton
Name.creator: Ximba, Lobolile
